title: The Power of Surrender
devotional:
Eliza loved the old oak tree at the edge of her property. It had stood there for generations, a silent sentinel watching over the changing seasons. In her younger years, she would try to climb it, reaching for the sky with childish abandon. As she grew older, she'd sit beneath its branches, seeking solace in its shade and wisdom in the rustling of its leaves. She imagined she was surrendering her problems to the trees. She would say: Please take these from me. You are so big and strong, and I trust you. But lately, Eliza had become preoccupied with its upkeep. The tree needed trimming, its roots were encroaching on her garden, and she worried about its stability in the face of upcoming storms.

One blustery afternoon, as Eliza fretted about the oak, a wise old neighbor, Mr. Abernathy, noticed her distress. He chuckled softly and said, "Eliza, sometimes the greatest strength comes from surrender. You're trying so hard to control the tree, but perhaps it's time to let go and trust its natural resilience." Eliza frowned, unsure of what he meant.

Mr. Abernathy explained, "The tree has weathered countless storms on its own. It bends with the wind, but it doesn't break. It knows when to shed its leaves and when to sprout anew. You can't control the weather, Eliza, and you can't control the tree's every move. But you can trust that it will endure, just as God endures in your life. Surrender your anxieties to Him." He added that, much like the tree, that sometimes you have to trim parts of your life so you can be strong and flourish.

Eliza pondered his words. She realized she'd been so focused on controlling the situation that she'd forgotten to trust in the oak's inherent strength and God's provision. That evening, as the wind howled, Eliza prayed, surrendering her worries about the tree and her life to God. She realized that in surrendering, she wasn’t giving up; she was freeing herself to focus on what truly mattered – her faith and her connection to God. She also understood that Surrender does not equal 'not caring'; it means to give the matter to God while you give what you can to the situation.

The next morning, the oak stood tall and unyielding, a testament to its resilience and the power of surrender. Eliza learned that true peace comes not from controlling our circumstances, but from surrendering them to God's loving care.
image_description: An old oak tree with gnarled branches reaching towards a cloudy sky at sunset, with the hint of green leaves budding.
insights: Eliza's story illustrates the biblical principle of surrendering our anxieties to God, as found in 1 Peter 5:7: 'Cast all your anxiety on him because he cares for you.' This verse doesn't promise a life free of challenges, but it assures us that God is always present and willing to bear our burdens. Similarly, Matthew 6:25-34 encourages us not to worry about the future but to seek first God's kingdom and righteousness, trusting that He will provide for our needs. Just like Eliza gave the problems to the tree, you can give your problems to God
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often struggle to surrender my worries and anxieties to You. I try to control every aspect of my life, forgetting that You are in control. Help me to trust in Your wisdom and provision, knowing that You care for me deeply. Teach me to release my fears and surrender my will to Your loving guidance. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: What areas of your life are you currently trying to control? How can you practice surrendering these areas to God? What does it mean to 'cast all your anxiety on him'? How can you remember to do that in the moment when you start to worry?
